node.text: The fast-spreading #deltavariant is raising fresh health concerns even in places where Covid vaccination rates are high. Senior pharmaceuticals analyst Sam Fazeli is here to tell you what you need to know.

node.text:
"Donald Trump upended the American presidency after stepping away from the company that made him rich and famous. Four years later, returning to his empire after losing the White House, what he finds may upend him," write Sophie Alexander and Max Abelson.

"Three quarters of Trump's net worth is tied up in urban real estate. And urban real estate has been hammered by Covid-19," Tim O'Brien tells @quicktake's Tim Stenovec.

The former president's net worth is down to $2.3 billion from $3 billion in 2016. The pandemic he promised would disappear is walloping his company, and the riot that got him impeached for a second time is wounding his brand.

Check out "Trump’s Ailing Empire" on bloomberg.com/graphics to see just how deep in peril he really is.

node.text:
👻 Snap Inc. is rolling out a new tool for its Snapchat app to feature popular videos, called Spotlight, and said it will pay out $1 million a day to creators of the top-performing posts. How good of a deal is that?

🤳🏻 "The more remarkable thing about Snap is that it wasn't offering these sort of incentives to people to create good content previously."

Alex Webb joined @quicktake's Tim Steno to explain why Snap decided to compensate viral creators.

#snapchat #influencer #app #creators #snap

node.title: Snapchat to Pay $1 Million a Day to Creators

node.text:
It’s been 20 months since a pair of fatal crashes forced regulators around the globe to ground the once top-selling jet. The FAA finally approved the Max to resume commercial flights today, which will allow Boeing to make money off the roughly 450 Max jets it has built but not yet delivered.

After the longest grounding of an aircraft in modern U.S. history, it’s reasonable to ask whether the plane is safe. Bloomberg Opinion columnists Chris Bryant and Brooke Sutherland teamed up to discuss the future of the Max, and whether or not they'd be willing to board one.

#Boeing #Boeing737 #737max #airplane #aircraft #airline #southwest #americanair #flight #pandemic #livestream #video #igtv #travel

node.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Is Back. Are You Willing to Board?

node.text:
Frank Barry didn’t ask a soul about Donald Trump or Joe Biden on his @looking4lincoln trip. For the two months he spent crossing the country along the Lincoln Highway by Winnebago, talking with Americans and hoping to reach San Francisco by Election Day, he never brought up the campaign. Sometimes he knew how people felt — occasionally they would say, though usually not. But it didn’t matter. He wasn’t running a focus group. He was trying to catch glimpses of a more enduring spirit, the kind that has transcended parties and generations, the kind that lives, as Lincoln said, in the better angels of our nature. And maybe those glimpses could help us see more of ourselves in each other, and in the land we share.

#lincolnhighway #travel #rv #roadtrip #winnebago #highway #ontheroad #interview #video

node.title: The End of the Lincoln Highway

node.text:
“It was really impossible not to feel the immediacy, the urgency of climate change on this leg of the trip.”

Frank Barry stops in #Iowa and #Colorado, continuing his journey across the U.S. along the Lincoln Highway.

Video by @quicktake, footage by @looking4lincoln.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 12, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Ibought Apple stock If Ihad held onto it, 2002. 3,800% Ⅲ Playlists Favorites Monday Morning Party Mix Road Trip Top5 Break-Up Songs Workout Tunes menu BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
"The worst sale I ever made?" Apple.

In 2002, Apple’s shares were trading at $15, with $13 a share in cash on the balance sheet. Barry Ritholtz did not see a lot of risk in the shares. He pitched it to his firm’s 800 or so brokers, many of whom bought lots of shares.

But he was surprised when soon after, and the shares shot up to $20, the brokers began to sell. “Up big, 33%, gotta ring the bell,” is what he was told.

He held on, and finally sold when his “stop loss” order was triggered on a pullback after the shares reached $45, leaving him with a 300% gain.

“A triple!” he smugly declared, in what was probably the worst sale he ever made.

"I may have paid $15 a share, but that was numerous splits ago, which means that had I held onto that Apple stock through last year, my post-split cost basis would have been 26.78 cents per share. That was about $2.4 trillion dollars in Apple’s market capitalization ago," Ritholtz writes.

In a career filled with other bad trades, missed opportunities and judgment errors, some decisions stand out, not just for the lost money, but for the lessons learned. Tap the link in our bio to read what Ritholtz's worst trades taught him about investing.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 12, 2021. May be an image of food and text that says 'Your chicken may be treated humanely, but what aoon the slaughterhouse workers? BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
There’s a massive wealth gap in the United States, but there’s also a moral inequality that reinforces the economic kind.

"You have these stigmatized and, in many cases defiling, jobs that end up being delegated to people with fewer opportunities," explains Eyal Press, author of "Dirty Work: Essential Jobs and the Hidden Toll of Inequality in America."

Who works on the floor of the slaughterhouse? It’s immigrants, exploited, who accept conditions that many native-born Americans don’t tolerate— like fast line speeds that cause huge rates of physical injury, or being denied bathroom breaks. It’s an incredible assault on one’s dignity.

"A lot of Americans are disgusted by and have growing awareness about the conditions in industrial slaughterhouses. What you have is a demand for labels like “humanely raised” to be placed on meat. But I suggest in the book that virtuous consumption has limits. The chicken may be humanely raised, but what happens to the workers? The label doesn’t say “humanely treated workers.” I think we need a deeper public reckoning about the kinds of dirty work that we allow to have done in our name," says Press.

Tap the link in our bio to read Clara Ferreira Marques's full discussion with Press.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 12, 2021. May be an image of dog and text that says 'Now you can buy one 17 billionth of a picture of adog BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Let’s say you have bought a picture of a dog online for $4 million. The picture of the dog carries no cash flows and no real exclusive rights — it is just a digital picture of a dog, anyone can copy it and use it and look at it to their heart’s content. But, you see, you have an exclusive pointer to the dog picture on some blockchain.

And it’s funny to “own” this picture of a dog on the blockchain. And you made a lot of money investing in crypto and it feels sort of fake anyway. Why not blow $4 million on a picture of a dog, who cares, easy come easy go.

Now you sell “shares” of the picture of the dog. How many shares? Who cares? Each share carries precisely no cash flows and no rights to the picture of the dog, so it doesn’t really matter how many shares you sell. How much are the shares worth? I dunno, I mean, in one sense, you paid $4 million for the picture of the dog, so when you slice it into shares their total value should be about $4 million. Like, 1% of the picture of the dog should be worth $40,000.

Or not: "Just three months after a non-fungible token (NFT) representing an image of the original Shiba Inu dogecoin meme sold for about $4 million, the NFT is now valued at more than $225 million after part of its ownership sold for over 11,000 ether."

Look. The fact that the picture of the dog originally sold for $4 million is a totally arbitrary fact, driven by comedic value and status competition and weird market dynamics among crypto millionaires. The fact that 20% of it sold for $45 million is also totally arbitrary! There is no reason those two numbers should be related to each other at all! Why should 20% of a picture of a dog be worth 20% as much as the picture of the dog? Neither of those things is anything!

Tap the link in our bio to read Matt Levine's Money Stuff in full.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'China's income inequality hasn't changed since Xi became president China income Gini coefficient 0.49 0.48 0.47 0.46 0.45 0.44 0.43 2003 0.42 2005 0.41 2010 0.40 2015 Source:NationalBureauofStatistios 2019 BloombergOpinion Bloomberg'.

node.text:
🇨🇳Xi Jinping’s increased use of “common prosperity” in speeches this year leaves us wondering: Why now?

Xi has been in power for more than eight years. China’s income inequality is wide — albeit not as bad as some countries, such as Brazil and India — but the trend hasn’t changed significantly since he became president in 2013.

"The stridency of this year’s inequality rhetoric is hard to square with the government’s relative inaction during that period, especially when China’s own researchers in partnership with the World Bank pointed out the urgency of these changes as far back as 2012," writes Matthew Brooker.

That suggests there is more going on here than a straightforward impulse to improve the lot of those left behind by China’s spectacular economic rise.

Tap the link in our bio to find out what's motivating Xi.

node.text:
In Ali Soufan’s previous life as an FBI special agent, he investigated and supervised some of the most important terrorism cases of our time, including the 1998 East Africa embassy bombings, the 2000 bombing of the USS Cole and the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

On the 20th anniversary of 9/11, he spoke with @ghoshworld: “It’s very difficult to think that 9/11 happened 20 years ago. For me, it feels as if it was yesterday. I was in the middle of the whole thing... Everything that happened after that for 20 years — all the mistakes we’ve made — it adds salt to that wound.”

#september11 #911 #neverforget

May be an image of text that says 'Public concern about terrorism has remained very high since 9/11 Concern about terrorism has held steadier in polling than in internet behavior Gallup (percent worried or very worried that they family member will be terror victim) Google Trends (index of search interest in "terrorism," maximum =100) 100 Paris terror attacks Boston Marathon bombing 50 Aynhh 1995 2000 Source:Gallup;GoogleTrends 2010 nmalh 2020 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and the American reaction to them, keep reverberating.

"Public concern about terrorism understandably rose after the attacks. It has remained stubbornly high in the two decades since if you go by Gallup polls," writes Justin Fox.

These polls have consistently found that between about 40% and 50% of Americans are very or somewhat worried that they or members of their family will be victims of terrorism.

The web search activity tracked since 2004 by Google, on the other hand, shows a big decline in “terrorism” searches since then, albeit interrupted by occasional spikes around news-making terrorist attacks.

Much of what seems broken in the U.S. today, journalist Spencer Ackerman writes in his new book “Reign of Terror: How the 9/11 Era Destabilized America and Produced Trump,” can be traced to the actions and reactions of the early 2000s.

Tap the link in our bio to read Fox's column: "The Economic Impact of 9/11, in 10 Charts."

#911 #neverforget #chart #data #sept11

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Gaming will change humanity as know weknowit it BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🎮 Whether or not you belong to the world of gaming, it is coming for your worlds.

Gaming is profoundly transforming two central aspects of the modern world: culture and regulation. There will be no turning back. 

Most of today’s cultural experts know very little about gaming, and they get on just fine. The worlds of culture and gaming are largely separate.

If you wish to create a new economic institution, put it inside a game. Or how about an app that gamifies share trading? Try the world of gaming, perhaps combined with crypto, and eventually your “game” might influence events in the real world.

To date, the regulators have tried to be strict. It is currently difficult to build fully realized new worlds without creating something that is legally defined as an unregistered security.

Both the culture-weakening and the regulation-weakening features of games follow from their one basic characteristic: They are self-contained worlds.

node.text:
At a high level, the business of Bitcoin mining is the business of finding the cheapest possible electricity.

But most of the electricity that you use, most of the time, is free, or at least “free.” If you use electricity at your house you pay for it. But that’s the exception. If you go to a coffee shop you can buy a muffin, plug in your laptop and sit for an hour, they generally won’t charge you for electricity. If you go to your office, you can turn on your computer and charge your phone. All free. Free electricity everywhere.

Of course you are expected to use only a reasonable personal amount of that free electricity, but if you ignore those expectations, a certain amount of scamming is possible:

"A Long Island man was charged on Wednesday with using his position as an I.T. supervisor for Suffolk County to mine cryptocurrency from government offices, costing the county thousands of dollars in electricity. Prosecutors said that Christopher Naples, 42, of Mattituck, L.I., had hidden 46 specialized devices used to mine Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies in six rooms in the Suffolk County Center in Riverhead, including underneath floorboards and inside an unused electrical panel."

Ahahaha well sure.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 10, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and text that says 'GoldmanSachsneedsthis IPO togo extremely well BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Naturally, Goldman Sachs wants every initial public offering it’s involved in to go well. But the bank has a lot riding on one in particular: the potential London listing of Petershill Partners.

This vehicle for owning stakes in private-equity firms could be a hot property, writes Chris Hughes. In July, Petershill's rival Bridgepoint listed at around 23 times next year’s estimated earnings. This multiple would value Petershill at nearly $6 billion.

Today, Bridgepoint is already trading at 34 times forecast 2022 earnings, so the temptation will be to push for something closer to where this stellar comparative firm is changing hands now rather than its valuation on recent listing.

But if there’s one deal Goldman should want to price attractively for investors, rather than for perfection, it’s this one. Tap the link in our bio to read all about Goldman's golden opportunity with Petershill.

May be an image of text that says 'China's middle class already outnumbers the poor and the elite Under $10,000 A significant portion of Chinese adults are in the middle-income bracket, making them better off than the average adult in the rest of the world $100,000 $1 million $10,000 $100,000 India Over $1 million Latin America United States World Europe China 0 50 Source: Credit Suisse ResearchInstitute 100 % BloombergOpinion Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Investors are desperately trying to decrypt China's “common prosperity” proclamation to understand what the real-world implications will be. They only have to look to the last 15 years: It’ll be more of the same.

It’s exactly what state planners had in mind over a decade ago when they started thinking about moving toward an olive-shaped society, where the middle class outnumbers the poor and the elite.

"In the decade that followed, China’s industrial policies became more focused. The top-down approach was used to modernize and push technological development that led to the rise of many successful — and several subpar — companies," writes Anjani Trivedi.

Investors fear the widening crackdown across China’s tech sector means Beijing is killing innovation and growth. But is it? Tap the link in our bio to find out.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in El Salvador. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and text that says 'total Atotalfailurein failurei El Salvador won't doom Bitcoin, butit could thwart crypto's evolution A VoU OIN BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Bitcoin had a rough week, slumping almost 10% on Tuesday — a day that should have been cause for a celebratory rally.

For the first time, Bitcoin became legal tender in a sovereign nation, El Salvador.  But technical glitches around the rollout and demonstrations against crypto adoption spoiled the debut and sent other digital currencies lower in sympathy.

The problems point to a greater unknown that may be far more significant in shaping Bitcoin’s evolution: Will people actually adopt it?

El Salvador is a test case of how crypto can flourish with active government support and encouragement. If crypto cannot find rapid and enthusiastic adoption under these conditions, investors have to rethink its overall value proposition.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about what's at stake for El Salvador.

node.text:
Marvel's “Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings” was such a hit that it resulted in record admissions revenue for the U.S. Labor Day weekend at AMC — yes, a record even amid the pandemic.

But jubilant shareholders of the theater chain are misreading a situation that instead reinforces an unfortunate truth: AMC’s future is beholden to the decisions of one powerful Hollywood operator, Walt Disney.

Adam Aron, CEO of AMC, has used his company’s 15 minutes of meme-stock fame to raise money, reduce the self-inflicted burden of its debt load and drum up enthusiasm by appealing to Main Street investors’ nostalgia and underdog mentality," writes Tara Lachapelle.

He has masterfully recast AMC as purely a pandemic victim. Even if that were the case, revenue and Ebitda estimates for 2022 and 2023 — which are still below pre-Covid levels — remain the elephant in the room.

Tap the link in our bio to read more.
